In mathematics, '''infinite [[composition (mathematics)|compositions]] of [[analytic function]]s (ICAF)''' offer alternative formulations of [[Generalized continued fraction|analytic continued fractions]], [[series (mathematics)|series]], [[product (mathematics)|products]] and other infinite expansions, and the theory evolving from such compositions may shed light on the [[convergence (mathematics)|convergence/divergence]] of these expansions. Some functions can actually be expanded directly as infinite compositions. In addition, it is possible to use ICAF to evaluate solutions of [[fixed point (mathematics)|fixed point]] equations involving infinite expansions. [[Complex dynamics]] offers another venue for [[iterated function system|iteration of systems of functions]] rather than a single function. For infinite compositions of a ''single function'' see [[Iterated function]]. For compositions of a finite number of functions, useful in [[fractal]] theory, see [[Iterated function system]].
Although the title of this article specifies analytic functions, there are results for more general [[Complex analysis|functions of a complex variable]] as well.
==Notation== There are several notations describing infinite compositions, including the following:
'''Forward compositions:''' {{math|''F<sub>k,n</sub>''(''z'') {{=}} ''f<sub>k</sub>'' ∘ ''f''<sub>''k''+1</sub> ∘ ... ∘ ''f''<sub>''n''−1</sub> ∘ ''f<sub>n</sub>''(''z'').}}
'''Backward compositions:''' {{math|''G<sub>k,n</sub>''(''z'') {{=}} ''f<sub>n</sub>'' ∘ ''f''<sub>''n''−1</sub> ∘ ... ∘ ''f''<sub>''k''+1</sub> ∘ ''f<sub>k</sub>''(''z'')}}
In each case convergence is interpreted as the existence of the following limits:
:<math> \lim_{n\to \infty} F_{1,n}(z), \qquad \lim_{n\to\infty} G_{1,n}(z).</math>
For convenience, set {{math|''F<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') {{=}} ''F''<sub>1,''n''</sub>(''z'')}} and {{math|''G<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') {{=}} ''G''<sub>1,''n''</sub>(''z'')}}.
One may also write <math>F_n(z)=\underset{k=1}{\overset{n}{\mathop R}}\,f_k(z)=f_1 \circ f_2\circ \cdots \circ f_n(z)</math> and <math>G_n(z)=\underset{k=1}{\overset{n}{\mathop L}}\,g_k(z)=g_n \circ g_{n-1}\circ \cdots \circ g_1(z)</math>
==Contraction theorem== Many results can be considered extensions of the following result:
:'''Contraction Theorem for Analytic Functions.'''<ref>P. Henrici, ''Applied and Computational Complex Analysis'', Vol. 1 (Wiley, 1974)</ref> Let ''f'' be analytic in a simply-connected region ''S'' and continuous on the closure {{overline|''S''}} of ''S''. Suppose ''f''({{overline|''S''}}) is a bounded set contained in ''S''. Then for all ''z'' in {{overline|''S''}} there exists an [[Fixed point (mathematics)#Attractive fixed points|attractive fixed point]] α of ''f'' in ''S'' such that: ::<math>F_n(z)=(f\circ f\circ \cdots \circ f)(z)\to \alpha,</math>
==Infinite compositions of contractive functions== Let {''f<sub>n</sub>''} be a sequence of functions analytic on a simply-connected domain ''S''. Suppose there exists a compact set Ω ⊂ ''S'' such that for each ''n'', ''f<sub>n</sub>''(''S'') ⊂ Ω.
:'''Forward (inner or right) Compositions Theorem.''' {''F<sub>n</sub>''} converges uniformly on compact subsets of ''S'' to a constant function ''F''(''z'') = λ.<ref>L. Lorentzen, Compositions of contractions, J. Comp & Appl Math. 32 (1990)</ref>
:'''Backward (outer or left) Compositions Theorem.''' {''G<sub>n</sub>''} converges uniformly on compact subsets of ''S'' to γ ∈ Ω if and only if the sequence of fixed points {''γ<sub>n</sub>''} of the {''f<sub>n</sub>''} converges to ''γ''.<ref name = Gilla>J. Gill, The use of the sequence {{math|''F<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') {{=}} ''f<sub>n</sub>'' ∘ ... ∘ ''f''<sub>1</sub>(''z'')}} in computing the fixed points of continued fractions, products, and series, Appl. Numer. Math. 8 (1991)</ref>
Additional theory resulting from investigations based on these two theorems, particularly Forward Compositions Theorem, include location analysis for the limits obtained here [http://comet.lehman.cuny.edu/keenl/blochconstantsfinalversion.pdf]. For a different approach to Backward Compositions Theorem, see [http://comet.lehman.cuny.edu/keenl/forwarditer.pdf].
Regarding Backward Compositions Theorem, the example ''f''<sub>2''n''</sub>(''z'') = 1/2 and ''f''<sub>2''n''−1</sub>(''z'') = −1/2 for ''S'' = {''z'' : |''z''| < 1} demonstrates the inadequacy of simply requiring contraction into a compact subset, like Forward Compositions Theorem.
For functions not necessarily analytic the [[Contraction mapping|Lipschitz]] condition suffices:
:'''Theorem.'''<ref name=Gill>J. Gill, A Primer on the Elementary Theory of Infinite Compositions of Complex Functions, Comm. Anal. Th. Cont. Frac., Vol XXIII (2017) and researchgate.net</ref> Suppose <math>S</math> is a simply connected compact subset of <math>\C</math> and let <math>t_n : S \to S</math> be a family of functions that satisfies ::<math> \forall n, \forall z_1, z_2 \in S, \exists \rho: \quad \left|t_n(z_1)-t_n(z_2) \right|\le \rho |z_1-z_2|, \quad \rho < 1.</math> :Define: ::<math>\begin{align} G_n(z) &= \left (t_n\circ t_{n-1}\circ \cdots \circ t_1 \right ) (z) \\ F_n(z) &= \left (t_1 \circ t_2\circ \cdots \circ t_n \right ) (z) \end{align}</math> :Then <math>F_n(z)\to \beta \in S</math> uniformly on <math>S.</math> If <math>\alpha_n</math> is the unique fixed point of <math>t_n</math> then <math>G_n(z)\to \alpha </math> uniformly on <math>S</math> if and only if <math>|\alpha_n -\alpha|=\varepsilon_n \to 0</math>.
==Infinite compositions of other functions==
=== Non-contractive complex functions === Results<ref name=Gillb /> involving '''[[entire function]]s''' include the following, as examples. Set
:<math>\begin{align} f_n(z)&=a_n z + c_{n,2}z^2+c_{n,3} z^3+\cdots \\ \rho_n &= \sup_r \left\{ \left| c_{n,r} \right|^{\frac{1}{r-1}} \right\} \end{align}</math>
Then the following results hold:
:'''Theorem E1.'''<ref name=Kojima>S.Kojima, Convergence of infinite compositions of entire functions, arXiv:1009.2833v1</ref> If ''a<sub>n</sub>'' ≡ 1, ::<math>\sum_{n=1}^\infty \rho_n < \infty</math> :then ''F<sub>n</sub>'' → ''F'', entire.
:'''Theorem E2.'''<ref name=Gillb>J. Gill, John Gill Mathematics Notes, researchgate.net</ref> Set ε<sub>''n''</sub> = |''a<sub>n</sub>''−1| suppose there exists non-negative δ<sub>''n''</sub>, ''M''<sub>1</sub>, ''M''<sub>2</sub>, ''R'' such that the following holds: ::<math>\begin{align} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \varepsilon_n &< \infty, \\ \sum_{n=1}^\infty \delta_n &< \infty, \\ \prod_{n=1}^\infty (1+\delta_n) &< M_1, \\ \prod_{n=1}^\infty (1+\varepsilon_n) &< M_2, \\ \rho_n &< \frac{\delta_n}{R M_1 M_2}. \end{align}</math> :Then ''G<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') → ''G''(''z''), analytic for |''z''| < ''R''. Convergence is uniform on compact subsets of {''z'' : |''z''| < ''R''}.
'''Additional elementary results include:'''
:'''Theorem GF3.'''<ref name=Gill /> Suppose <math>f_n(z)=z+\rho_n \varphi (z)</math> where there exist <math>R, M>0</math> such that <math>|z|<R</math> implies <math>| \varphi(z)|<M.</math> Furthermore, suppose <math>\rho_k\ge 0, \sum_{k=1}^\infty \rho_k<\infty </math> and <math>R>M\sum_{k=1}^\infty \rho_k.</math> Then for <math>R*<R-M\sum_{k=1}^n \rho_k</math> ::<math>G_n(z)\equiv \left (f_n\circ f_{n-1}\circ \cdots \circ f_1 \right ) (z) \to G(z) \qquad \text{ for } \{z:|z|<R*\}</math>
:'''Theorem GF4.'''<ref name=Gill /> Suppose <math>f_n(z)=z+\rho_n \varphi (z)</math> where there exist <math>R, M>0</math> such that <math>|z|<R</math> and <math>|\zeta|<R</math> implie <math>|\varphi (z)|<M</math> and <math>|\varphi (z)-\varphi (\zeta)|\le r|z-\zeta|.</math> Furthermore, suppose <math>\rho_k\ge 0, \sum_{k=1}^\infty \rho_k < \infty </math> and <math>R>M \sum_{k=1}^{\infty }\rho_k.</math> Then for <math>R*<R-M\sum_{k=1}^{n}\rho_k</math> ::<math>F_n(z)\equiv \left (f_1\circ f_2\circ \cdots \circ f_n \right) (z) \to F(z) \qquad \text{ for } \{z:|z|<R*\}</math>
:'''Theorem GF5.'''<ref name=Gillb /> Let <math>f_n(z)=z+ zg_n(z),</math> analytic for |''z''| < ''R''<sub>0</sub>, with |''g<sub>n</sub>''(''z'')| ≤ ''C''β<sub>''n''</sub>, ::<math>\sum_{n=1}^\infty \beta_n<\infty.</math> :Choose 0 < ''r'' < ''R''<sub>0</sub> and define ::<math>R=R(r)=\frac{R_0-r}{\prod_{n=1}^\infty (1+C\beta_n)}.</math> :Then ''F<sub>n</sub>'' → ''F'' uniformly for |''z''| ≤ ''R''. Furthermore, ::<math>\left| F'(z) \right|\le \prod_{n=1}^\infty \left( 1+\tfrac{R_0}{r} C\beta_n \right).</math>
'''Example GF1''': <math>F_{40}(x+iy)=\underset{k=1}{\overset{40}{\mathop R}} \left( \frac{x+iy}{1+\tfrac{1}{4^k} (x\cos(y)+iy\sin(x))} \right), \qquad [-20,20]</math>
[[File:Reproductive_universe.jpg|thumb|center|350px|Example GF1:Reproductive universe – A topographical (moduli) image of an infinite composition.]]
'''Example GF2''': <math> G_{40}(x+iy)=\underset{k=1}{\overset{40}{\mathop L}}\,\left( \frac{x+iy}{1+\tfrac{1}{2^k} (x\cos(y)+iy\sin(x))} \right), \qquad [-20,20] </math>
[[File:Metropolis_at_30K.jpg|thumb|center|350px|Example GF2:Metropolis at 30K – A topographical (moduli) image of an infinite composition.]]
=== Linear fractional transformations === Results<ref name=Gillb /> for compositions of '''[[möbius transformation|linear fractional (Möbius) transformations]]''' include the following, as examples:
:'''Theorem LFT1.''' On the set of convergence of a sequence {''F<sub>n</sub>''} of non-singular LFTs, the limit function is either: :*(a) a non-singular LFT, :*(b) a function taking on two distinct values, or :*(c) a constant. In (a), the sequence converges everywhere in the extended plane. In (b), the sequence converges either everywhere, and to the same value everywhere except at one point, or it converges at only two points. Case (c) can occur with every possible set of convergence.<ref>G. Piranian & W. Thron,Convergence properties of sequences of Linear fractional transformations, Mich. Math. J.,Vol. 4 (1957)</ref>
:'''Theorem LFT2.'''<ref>J. DePree & W. Thron,On sequences of Mobius transformations, Math. Z., Vol. 80 (1962)</ref> If {''F<sub>n</sub>''} converges to an LFT, then ''f<sub>n</sub>'' converge to the identity function ''f''(''z'') = ''z''.
:'''Theorem LFT3.'''<ref>A. Magnus & M. Mandell, On convergence of sequences of linear fractional transformations,Math. Z. 115 (1970)</ref> If ''f<sub>n</sub>'' → ''f'' and all functions are ''hyperbolic'' or ''loxodromic'' Möbius transformations, then ''F<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') → ''λ'', a constant, for all <math>z \ne \beta = \lim_{n\to \infty} \beta_n</math>, where {''β<sub>n</sub>''} are the repulsive fixed points of the {''f<sub>n</sub>''}.
:'''Theorem LFT4.'''<ref>J. Gill, Infinite compositions of Mobius transformations, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., Vol176 (1973)</ref> If ''f<sub>n</sub>'' → ''f'' where ''f'' is ''parabolic'' with fixed point γ. Let the fixed-points of the {''f<sub>n</sub>''} be {γ<sub>''n''</sub>} and {''β<sub>n</sub>''}. If ::<math>\sum_{n=1}^\infty \left|\gamma_n-\beta_n \right| <\infty \quad \text{and} \quad \sum_{n=1}^\infty n \left|\beta_{n+1}-\beta_n \right|<\infty</math> :then ''F<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') → ''λ'', a constant in the extended complex plane, for all ''z''.
==Examples and applications==
=== Continued fractions === The value of the infinite continued fraction
:<math>\cfrac{a_1}{b_1+\cfrac{a_2}{b_2+\cdots}}</math>
may be expressed as the limit of the sequence {''F<sub>n</sub>''(0)} where
:<math>f_n(z)=\frac{a_n}{b_n+z}.</math>
As a simple example, a well-known result (Worpitsky Circle*<ref>L. Lorentzen, H. Waadeland, ''Continued Fractions with Applications'', North Holland (1992)</ref>) follows from an application of Theorem (A):
Consider the continued fraction
:<math>\cfrac{a_1\zeta }{1+\cfrac{a_2\zeta }{1+\cdots}} </math>
with
:<math>f_n(z)=\frac{a_n \zeta }{1+z}.</math>
Stipulate that |ζ| < 1 and |''z''| < ''R'' < 1. Then for 0 < ''r'' < 1,
: <math>|a_n|<rR(1-R)\Rightarrow \left|f_n(z) \right|<rR<R\Rightarrow \frac{a_1\zeta }{1+\frac{a_2\zeta }{1+\cdots}} = F(\zeta )</math>, analytic for |''z''| < 1. Set ''R'' = 1/2.
'''Example.''' <math>F(z)=\frac{(i-1)z}{1+i+z\text{ }+}\text{ }\frac{(2-i)z}{1+2i+z\text{ }+}\text{ }\frac{(3-i)z}{1+3i+z\text{ }+} \cdots, </math> <math>[-15,15]</math> [[File:Continued fraction1.jpg|thumb|center|350px|Example: Continued fraction1 – Topographical (moduli) image of a continued fraction (one for each point) in the complex plane. [−15,15]]]
'''Example.'''<ref name=Gillb /> A ''fixed-point continued fraction form'' (a single variable). :<math>f_{k,n}(z)=\frac{\alpha_{k,n} \beta_{k,n} }{\alpha_{k,n}+\beta_{k,n}-z}, \alpha_{k,n}=\alpha_{k,n}(z), \beta_{k,n}=\beta_{k,n}(z), F_n(z)= \left (f_{1,n} \circ\cdots \circ f_{n,n} \right ) (z)</math> :<math>\alpha_{k,n}=xcos(ty)+iysin(tx), \beta_{k,n}=cos(ty)+isin(tx), t=k/n</math>
[[File:Infinite Brooch.jpg|thumb|center|370px|Example: Infinite Brooch - Topographical (moduli) image of a ''continued fraction form'' in the complex plane. (6<x<9.6),(4.8<y<8)]]
=== Direct functional expansion === Examples illustrating the conversion of a function directly into a composition follow:
'''Example 1.'''<ref name=Kojima /><ref>N. Steinmetz, ''Rational Iteration'', Walter de Gruyter, Berlin (1993)</ref> Suppose <math>\phi</math> is an entire function satisfying the following conditions: :<math>\begin{cases} \phi (tz)=t\left( \phi (z)+\phi (z)^2 \right) & |t|> 1 \\ \phi(0) = 0 \\ \phi'(0) =1 \end{cases}</math> Then :<math>f_n(z)=z+\frac{z^2}{t^n}\Longrightarrow F_n(z)\to \phi (z)</math>.
'''Example 2.'''<ref name=Kojima /> :<math>f_n(z)=z+\frac{z^2}{2^n}\Longrightarrow F_n(z)\to \frac{1}{2}\left( e^{2z}-1 \right)</math>
'''Example 3.'''<ref name=Gillb /> :<math>f_n(z)= \frac{z}{1-\tfrac{z^2}{4^n}}\Longrightarrow F_n(z)\to \tan (z)</math>
'''Example 4.'''<ref name=Gillb /> :<math>g_n(z)=\frac{2 \cdot 4^{n}}{z} \left ( \sqrt{1+\frac{z^2}{4^{n}}}-1 \right )\Longrightarrow G_n(z) \to \arctan (z)</math>
=== Calculation of fixed-points === Theorem (B) can be applied to determine the fixed-points of functions defined by infinite expansions or certain integrals. The following examples illustrate the process:
'''Example FP1.'''<ref name=Gilla /> For |ζ| ≤ 1 let
:<math>G(\zeta )=\frac{ \tfrac{e^\zeta}{4}}{3+\zeta +\cfrac{\tfrac{e^\zeta} 8 }{3+\zeta + \cfrac{\tfrac{e^\zeta}{12}}{3+\zeta +\cdots}}}</math>
To find α = ''G''(α), first we define:
:<math>\begin{align} t_n(z)&=\cfrac{\tfrac{e^\zeta}{4n}}{3+\zeta +z} \\ f_n(\zeta )&= t_1\circ t_2\circ \cdots \circ t_n(0) \end{align}</math>
Then calculate <math>G_n(\zeta )=f_n\circ \cdots \circ f_1(\zeta )</math> with ζ = 1, which gives: α = 0.087118118... to ten decimal places after ten iterations.
:'''Theorem FP2.'''<ref name=Gillb /> Let φ(ζ, ''t'') be analytic in ''S'' = {''z'' : |''z''| < ''R''} for all ''t'' in [0, 1] and continuous in ''t''. Set ::<math>f_n (\zeta)=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^n \varphi \left( \zeta ,\tfrac{k}{n} \right).</math> :If |φ(ζ, ''t'')| ≤ ''r'' < ''R'' for ζ ∈ ''S'' and ''t'' ∈ [0, 1], then ::<math>\zeta =\int_0^1 \varphi (\zeta ,t) \, dt</math> :has a unique solution, α in ''S'', with <math>\lim_{n\to \infty} G_n(\zeta ) = \alpha. </math>
=== Evolution functions === Consider a time interval, normalized to ''I'' = [0, 1]. ICAFs can be constructed to describe continuous motion of a point, ''z'', over the interval, but in such a way that at each "instant" the motion is virtually zero (see [[Zeno's paradoxes|Zeno's Arrow]]): For the interval divided into n equal subintervals, 1 ≤ ''k'' ≤ ''n'' set <math>g_{k,n}(z)=z+\varphi_{k,n}(z)</math> analytic or simply continuous – in a domain ''S'', such that
:<math>\lim_{n\to \infty}\varphi_{k,n}(z)=0</math> for all ''k'' and all ''z'' in ''S'', and <math>g_{k,n}(z)\in S</math>.
==== Principal example<ref name=Gillb /> ====
:<math>\begin{align} g_{k,n}(z) &=z+\frac{1}{n}\phi \left (z,\tfrac{k}{n} \right ) \\ G_{k,n}(z) &= \left (g_{k,n}\circ g_{k-1,n} \circ \cdots \circ g_{1,n} \right ) (z) \\ G_n(z) &=G_{n,n}(z) \end{align}</math>
implies
:<math>\lambda_n(z)\doteq G_n(z)-z=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=1}^n \phi \left( G_{k-1,n}(z)\tfrac k n \right)\doteq \frac 1 n \sum_{k=1}^n \psi \left (z,\tfrac{k}{n} \right) \sim \int_0^1 \psi (z,t)\,dt,</math>
where the integral is well-defined if <math>\tfrac{dz}{dt}=\phi (z,t)</math> has a closed-form solution ''z''(''t''). Then
:<math>\lambda_n(z_0)\approx \int_0^1 \phi ( z(t),t)\,dt.</math>
Otherwise, the integrand is poorly defined although the value of the integral is easily computed. In this case one might call the integral a "virtual" integral.
'''Example.''' <math>\phi (z,t)=\frac{2t-\cos y}{1-\sin x\cos y}+i\frac{1-2t\sin x}{1-\sin x\cos y}, \int_0^1 \psi (z,t) \, dt</math> [[File:Virtual_tunnels.jpg|thumb|center|350px|Example 1: Virtual tunnels – Topographical (moduli) image of virtual integrals (one for each point) in the complex plane. [−10,10]]]
[[Image:Contours in the vector field f(z) = -Cos(z).jpg|thumb|right|350px|Two contours flowing towards an attractive fixed point (red on the left). The white contour (''c'' = 2) terminates before reaching the fixed point. The second contour (''c''(''n'') = square root of ''n'') terminates at the fixed point. For both contours, ''n'' = 10,000]]
'''Example.'''<ref>J. Gill, Informal Notes: Zeno contours, parametric forms, & integrals, Comm. Anal. Th. Cont. Frac., Vol XX (2014)</ref> Let:
:<math>g_n(z)=z+\frac{c_n}{n}\phi (z), \quad \text{with} \quad f(z) = z + \phi(z).</math>
Next, set <math>T_{1,n}(z)=g_n(z), T_{k,n}(z)= g_n(T_{k-1,n}(z)),</math> and ''T<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') = ''T<sub>n,n</sub>''(''z''). Let
:<math>T(z)=\lim_{n\to \infty} T_n(z)</math>
when that limit exists. The sequence {''T<sub>n</sub>''(''z'')} defines contours γ = γ(''c<sub>n</sub>'', ''z'') that follow the flow of the vector field ''f''(''z''). If there exists an attractive fixed point α, meaning |''f''(''z'') − α| ≤ ρ|''z'' − α| for 0 ≤ ρ < 1, then ''T<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') → ''T''(''z'') ≡ α along γ = γ(''c<sub>n</sub>'', ''z''), provided (for example) <math>c_n = \sqrt{n}</math>. If ''c<sub>n</sub>'' ≡ ''c'' > 0, then ''T<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') → ''T''(''z''), a point on the contour γ = γ(''c'', ''z''). It is easily seen that
:<math>\oint_\gamma \phi (\zeta ) \, d\zeta =\lim_{n\to \infty}\frac c n \sum_{k=1}^n \phi ^2 \left (T_{k-1,n}(z) \right )</math>
and
:<math>L(\gamma (z))=\lim_{n\to \infty} \frac{c}{n}\sum_{k=1}^n \left| \phi \left (T_{k-1,n}(z) \right ) \right|, </math>
when these limits exist.
These concepts are marginally related to ''[[Active contour model|active contour theory]]'' in image processing, and are simple generalizations of the [[Euler method]]
=== Self-replicating expansions ===
====Series==== The series defined recursively by ''f<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') = ''z'' + ''g<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') have the property that the nth term is predicated on the sum of the first ''n'' − 1 terms. In order to employ theorem (GF3) it is necessary to show boundedness in the following sense: If each ''f<sub>n</sub>'' is defined for |''z''| < ''M'' then |''G<sub>n</sub>''(''z'')| < ''M'' must follow before |''f<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') − ''z''| = |''g<sub>n</sub>''(''z'')| ≤ ''Cβ<sub>n</sub>'' is defined for iterative purposes. This is because <math>g_n(G_{n-1}(z))</math> occurs throughout the expansion. The restriction
:<math>|z|<R=M-C\sum_{k=1}^\infty \beta_k >0</math>
serves this purpose. Then ''G<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') → ''G''(''z'') uniformly on the restricted domain.
'''Example (S1).''' Set :<math>f_n(z)=z+\frac{1}{\rho n^2}\sqrt{z}, \qquad \rho >\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{6}}</math> and ''M'' = ρ<sup>2</sup>. Then ''R'' = ρ<sup>2</sup> − (π/6) > 0. Then, if <math>S=\left\{ z: |z|<R,\operatorname{Re}(z)>0 \right\}</math>, ''z'' in ''S'' implies |''G<sub>n</sub>''(''z'')| < ''M'' and theorem (GF3) applies, so that
:<math>\begin{align} G_n(z) &=z+g_1(z)+g_2(G_1(z))+g_3(G_2(z))+\cdots + g_n(G_{n-1}(z)) \\ &= z+\frac{1}{\rho \cdot 1^2}\sqrt{z}+\frac{1}{\rho \cdot 2^2}\sqrt{G_1(z)}+\frac{1}{\rho \cdot 3^2}\sqrt{G_2(z)}+\cdots +\frac{1}{\rho \cdot n^2} \sqrt{G_{n-1}(z)} \end{align}</math>
converges absolutely, hence is convergent.
'''Example (S2)''': <math>f_n(z)=z+\frac 1 {n^2}\cdot \varphi (z), \varphi (z)=2\cos(x/y)+i2\sin (x/y), >G_n(z)=f_n \circ f_{n-1}\circ \cdots \circ f_1(z), \qquad [-10,10], n=50 </math> [[File:Self-generating series3.jpg|thumb|center|325px|Example (S2)- A topographical (moduli) image of a self generating series.]]
====Products==== The product defined recursively by
:<math>f_n(z)=z( 1+g_n(z)), \qquad |z| \leqslant M,</math>
has the appearance
:<math>G_n(z) = z \prod _{k=1}^n \left( 1+g_k \left( G_{k-1}(z) \right) \right).</math>
In order to apply Theorem GF3 it is required that:
:<math>\left| zg_n(z) \right|\le C\beta_n, \qquad \sum_{k=1}^\infty \beta_k<\infty.</math>
Once again, a boundedness condition must support
:<math>\left|G_{n-1}(z) g_n(G_{n-1}(z))\right|\le C \beta_n.</math>
If one knows ''Cβ<sub>n</sub>'' in advance, the following will suffice:
:<math>|z| \leqslant R = \frac{M}{P} \qquad \text{where} \quad P = \prod_{n=1}^\infty \left( 1+C\beta_n\right).</math>
Then ''G<sub>n</sub>''(''z'') → ''G''(''z'') uniformly on the restricted domain.
'''Example (P1).''' Suppose <math>f_n(z)=z(1+g_n(z))</math> with <math>g_n(z)=\tfrac{z^2}{n^3},</math> observing after a few preliminary computations, that |''z''| ≤ 1/4 implies |''G<sub>n</sub>''(''z'')| < 0.27. Then
:<math>\left|G_n(z) \frac{G_n(z)^2}{n^3} \right|<(0.02)\frac{1}{n^3}=C\beta_n</math>
and
:<math>G_n(z)=z \prod_{k=1}^{n-1}\left( 1+\frac{G_k(z)^2}{n^3}\right)</math>
converges uniformly.
'''Example (P2).'''
:<math>g_{k,n}(z)=z\left( 1+\frac 1 n \varphi \left (z,\tfrac k n \right ) \right),</math> :<math>G_{n,n}(z)= \left ( g_{n,n}\circ g_{n-1,n}\circ \cdots \circ g_{1,n} \right ) (z) = z\prod_{k=1}^n ( 1+P_{k,n}(z)),</math> :<math>P_{k,n}(z)=\frac 1 n \varphi \left (G_{k-1,n}(z),\tfrac{k}{n} \right ),</math> :<math> \prod_{k=1}^{n-1} \left( 1+P_{k,n}(z) \right) = 1+P_{1,n}(z)+{{P}_{2,n}}(z)+\cdots +{{P}_{k-1,n}}(z) + R_n(z) \sim \int_0^1 \pi (z,t) \, dt + 1+R_n(z),</math>
:<math>\varphi (z)=x\cos(y)+i\cdot y\sin(x), \int_0^1 (z\pi (z,t)-1) \,dt, \qquad [-15,15]: </math> [[Image:Picasso's Universe.jpg|thumb|center|350px|Example (P2): Picasso's Universe – a derived virtual integral from a self-generating infinite product. Click on image for higher resolution.]]
====Continued fractions==== '''Example (CF1)''': A self-generating continued fraction.<ref name=Gillb /> [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/John_Gill6/contributions]
: <math>\begin{align} F_n(z) & =\frac{\rho (z)}{\delta_1+{}}\ \frac{\rho (F_1(z))}{\delta_2 +{}}\ \frac{\rho (F_2(z))}{\delta_3+}\ \cdots \ \frac{\rho (F_{n-1}(z))}{\delta_n}, \\ \rho (z) & =\frac{\cos (y)}{\cos (y)+\sin (x)}+i\frac{\sin (x)}{\cos (y)+\sin (x)}, \qquad [0<x<20],[0<y<20], \qquad\delta_k\equiv 1 \end{align}</math>
[[Image:Diminishing returns.jpg|thumb|center|350px|Example CF1: Diminishing returns – a topographical (moduli) image of a self-generating continued fraction.]]
'''Example (CF2)''': Best described as a self-generating reverse [[Euler's continued fraction formula|Euler continued fraction]].<ref name=Gillb />
: <math>G_n(z)=\frac{\rho (G_{n-1}(z))}{1+\rho (G_{n-1}(z))-}\ \frac{\rho (G_{n-2}(z))}{1+\rho (G_{n-2}(z))-}\cdots \frac{\rho (G_1(z))}{1+\rho (G_1(z))-}\ \frac{\rho (z)}{1+\rho (z)-z},</math> :<math>\rho (z)=\rho (x+iy)=x\cos(y)+iy\sin(x), \qquad [-15,15], n=30 </math>
[[Image:Dream of Gold.jpg|thumb|center|350px|Example CF2: Dream of Gold – a topographical (moduli) image of a self-generating reverse Euler continued fraction.]]

'''Jean-Claude Suares''' (March 30, 1942 – July 30, 2013) was an [[artist]], [[illustrator]], [[editor]], and [[creative consultant]] to many publications, and the first [[Op-Ed]] page [[art director]] at ''[[The New York Times]]''.
==Biography== Suares was born on March 30, 1942, in [[Alexandria, Egypt]], to a [[Sephardic]] father. He and his family moved from Egypt to [[Italy]] when he was a teenager. Later, he moved to [[New York City]], where he briefly attended [[Pratt Institute]]. In the 1960s, he joined the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] [[paratrooper]]s and was sent to [[Vietnam]], where he worked on staff for ''[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]''. He also spoke several languages. In 1973, Suares arranged an exhibition of Op-Ed art at the [[Musée des Arts Décoratifs, Paris|Musée des Arts Décoratifs]] in [[Paris]]. For over 30 years his comic drawings appeared in ''The New York Times'', on the covers of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' and ''[[The Atlantic Monthly]]'', and in other periodicals and books. He wrote, edited or designed scores of illustrated books. He was also involved in book publishing. He worked with [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis]] at [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]]. He also designed [[Michael Jackson]]’s autobiography, ''[[Moonwalk (book)|Moonwalk]]''. Suares was in one movie in 1973, ''It Happened in Hollywood''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jean Claude Suares|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3478117/|publisher=IMDb|accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref>
A resident of [[Harrington Park, New Jersey]], Suares died on July 30, 2013, at [[Englewood Hospital and Medical Center]] in [[Englewood, New Jersey]] as a result of a [[bacterial infection]].<ref>Levin, Jay. [http://www.northjersey.com/obituaries/218631401_Jean-Claude_Suares_of_Harrington_Park__illustrator_and_graphic_designer__dies_at_71.html "Jean-Claude Suares of Harrington Park, illustrator and graphic designer, dies at 71"], ''[[The Record (Bergen County)]]'', "Jean-Claude Suares of Harrington Park, an illustrator, graphic designer and creative consultant whose work embellished major publications and dozens of books, notably those on a topic dear to him — dogs and cats — died July 30 at Englewood Hospital and Medical Center. He was 71."</ref> He was 71 and is survived by his wife of 33 years [[Nina Duran]], and a sister.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jean-Claude Suares|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/northjersey/obituary.aspx?n=jean-claude-suares&pid=166247492#fbLoggedOut|publisher=NewJersey.com|accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Jean-Claude Suares, Daring Illustrator of The Times’s Op-Ed Page, Dies at 71|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/06/business/media/jean-claude-suares-daring-illustrator-of-the-timess-op-ed-page-dies-at-71.html|publisher=NY Times|accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref>

page.title: List of killings by law enforcement officers in the United Kingdom

revision.text:
{{Expand list|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} This '''list of people killed by law enforcement officers in the United Kingdom''' documents cases of people who died directly or indirectly because of the actions of British [[law enforcement officers]], regardless of the manner of death, duty status of the officers, or if they acted officially or unofficially. It includes officers working for [[List of law enforcement agencies in the United Kingdom|all law enforcement agencies]], existing or historical, in [[England]], [[Wales]], [[Scotland]], and [[Northern Ireland]], but excludes [[crown dependencies]], [[British colonies|colonies]] or other political entities subject or previously subjected to the direct control of the [[government of the United Kingdom]]. It also excludes deaths for which other government agents are responsible, such as deaths as a result of actions of the [[British Armed Forces]]. Earlier deaths in the mid-20th century also may not as be well documented; only deaths which have been confirmed by press releases or other media sources are listed.
==Single deaths==
=== Since 2000 === <!--Include the day in the date: Date sorting does not work for columns with only the month before the year--> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Name ! Date ! Location ! Description |- |Richard Cottier |9 April 2018 |[[Romford]], London |Officers responded when Cottier called the police in the early hours of the morning informing them that he had taken an overdose and alleging that he had a firearm in his possession. A further call from a member of the public reporting a man with a firearm was also received. Cottier was located at the Esso petrol station on Collier Row Road and officers fired two shots. He died at the scene<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.romfordrecorder.co.uk/news/man-shot-dead-by-police-in-collier-row-named-by-investigators-1-5481213|title=Man shot dead by police in Collier Row named by investigators|last=Coleman|first=Liam|work=Romford Recorder|access-date=2018-08-29|language=en}}</ref>. He was shot at about 04:45 BST and was pronounced dead at 05:17<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-43696771|title=Police shoot man dead in east London|date=2018-04-09|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-08-29|language=en-GB}}</ref>. |- |Spencer Ashworth |27 September 2017 |[[Portishead, Somerset|Portishead]], Somerset |At around 9:30 in the morning, officers fired shots at a car on the [[A369 road|A369]] resulting in the death of Ashworth. Avon and Somerset Police said it acted following reports of a man in a car with a handgun. It is also reported that Ashworth had threatened other motorists. W itnesses said Ashworth was shot up to 10 times through the passenger window before he was pulled from the car by officers who began attempting to resuscitate him. A non-police issued firearm was recovered at the scene of the shooting.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/portishead-shooting-man-killed-by-armed-police-on-a369-identified-as-spencer-ashworth_uk_59d24a29e4b06791bb11fb34|title=Man Killed By Armed Police In A369 Portishead Shooting Is Named|date=2017-10-02|work=HuffPost UK|access-date=2017-10-02|language=en-GB}}</ref> |- |[[Death of Edson Da Costa|Edson Da Costa]] | 21 June 2017 | [[Beckton]], London | Police stopped the car Da Costa was travelling in and subdued him with [[CS gas]]. A postmortem examination did not establish a cause of death. Police maintain they did not use excessive force; however, Da Costa's family alleged he was violently assaulted. A protest was later held, resulting in damage to Forest Gate police station. |- | [[2017 Westminster attack|Khalid Masood]]<ref>{{cite web|title=London attack: Police identify Westminster attacker|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-39372154|website=BBC News|date=23 March 2017}}</ref> | 22 March 2017 | Westminster, London |After using a [[Vehicle-ramming attack|vehicle to hit pedestrians]] on [[Westminster Bridge]], Masood entered the grounds of the [[Palace of Westminster]], where he fatally stabbed an unarmed police officer. An armed police officer, believed to have been the [[Protection Command|Metropolitan Police close protection officer]] for [[Michael Fallon]], the [[Secretary of State for Defence]], witnessed the stabbing, ran towards the scene and fatally shot Masood.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/03/22/man-shot-police-outside-parliament-officer-reportedly-shoots|title=Attack on Parliament March 22: The Westminster rampage at the heart of Britain's democracy|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-06-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> |- | Yassar Yaqub<ref>{{cite web|title=M62 shooting: Man dies in Huddersfield police operation|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leeds-38492953|website=BBC News|date=3 January 2017}}</ref> | 2 January 2017 | Huddersfield | Yaqub was shot by police at junction 24 of the M62, after they received a tip-off that he was armed and carrying a gun in the silver Audi in which he was a passenger.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/01/04/family-man-shot-dead-police-join-mp-appeal-calm-protests/|title='Stud badboy' shot on M62 by police used fast cars to launder profits from his drugs empire|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-06-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> |- | Lewis Skelton<ref>{{cite web|title=Hull shooting: Man dies after being wounded by police|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-humber-38142273|website=BBC News|date=29 November 2016}}</ref> | 29 November 2016 | Hull |Reportedly wielding an axe, Skelton was shot by armed response officers during the morning of 29 November. He was taken to hospital where he later died of his injuries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hulldailymail.co.uk/police-shooting-in-francis-street-leaves-hull-in-shock-after-man-dies/story-29945689-detail/story.html|title=Day that shocked Hull: Horror as man dies after police shooting|date=2016-11-30|work=Hull Daily Mail|access-date=2017-06-05|language=en}}</ref> |- | Josh Pitt<ref>{{cite web|title=Man dies in Luton police shooting|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-37927420|website=BBC News|date=9 November 2016}}</ref> | 9 November 2016 | Luton, Bedfordshire |Police responded to reports of woman being attacked in a house. Shortly after arriving on the scene, armed police officers shot Pitt. Pitt was treated at the scene by officers and paramedics before being taken to hospital, but was pronounced dead shortly after arriving at hospital. Police recovered a "number of knives" at the scene.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/first-picture-young-dad-shot-9260233|title=Young dad shot dead by police in Luton identified|last=Evans|first=Sophie|date=2016-11-14|work=mirror|access-date=2017-06-05}}</ref> |- | [[Dalian Atkinson]] | 15 August 2016 | Telford, Shropshire |Police had responded to a call as Atkinson threatened to kill his father, Ernest. Atkinson's older brother Kenroy said "My brother had lost it. He was in a manic state and depressed – out of his mind and ranting. He had a tube in his shoulder for the [[dialysis]] and he had ripped it out and was covered in blood. He got dad by the throat and said he was going to kill him. He told dad he had already killed me, our brother Paul and sister Elaine and he had come for him."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/08/16/ex-aston-villa-footballer-dalian-atkinson-threatened-to-kill-his/|title=Ex-Aston Villa footballer Dalian Atkinson threatened to kill his father before being tasered by police, brother reveals|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-06-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> After being tasered, Atkinson went into [[cardiac arrest]] on the way to the [[Princess Royal Hospital, Telford|Princess Royal Hospital]], where he was pronounced dead.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-37082207|title=Dalian Atkinson dies after being Tasered in Telford by police|date=2016-08-15|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-06-05|language=en-GB}}</ref> |- | William Smith<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=Man dies during armed police raid in Goudhurst, Kent|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-kent-36186840|website=BBC News|date=2 May 2016}}</ref> | 2 May 2016 | Goudhurst, Kent |[[Kent Police]] fatally shot Smith during an armed operation. Smith was on bail in connection with the death of a 73-year-old man in Kent.<ref name=":0" /> |- | James Wilson<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-tyne-35950358|title=Northumbria Police shooting: Man shot by officers in South Shields dies|accessdate=2 April 2016|date=3 April 2016}}</ref> | 29 March 2016 | South Shields, Northumbria |James Wilson was shot in the chest by officers who were called to Frenchman's Way in the early hours of 29 March after reports of a man in the street with a handgun.
Wilson was taken to Newcastle's Royal Victoria Infirmary, but died late on 1 April.<ref name=":1" /> |- | Jermaine Baker<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/dec/14/homicide-inquiry-launched-after-suspect-shot-dead-by-police-in-london|title=Police firearms officer suspended after fatal shooting of suspect in London|accessdate=15 December 2015|date=14 December 2015}}</ref> | 11 December 2015 | Wood Green, London |[[Specialist Firearms Command|Metropolitan Police Service]] specialist firearms officers were involved in stopping an attempt to intercept a secure van transporting prisoners. Three men were planning to free Izzet Eren who was being taken in a prison van to Wood Green crown court over firearms offences. Baker was in the front seat of a vehicle with two other occupants where he received a fatal single gunshot wound as police surrounded his vehicle. He was unarmed, although there was an [[Airsoft gun|imitation]] [[Uzi]] in the rear foot-well behind the driver’s seat.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Independent investigation into the fatal shooting of a man by police in north London|url=https://www.ipcc.gov.uk/news/independent-investigation-fatal-shooting-man-police-north-london|website=Independent Police Complaints Commission|accessdate=29 September 2017|date=11 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Dodd|first1=Vikram|title=Met officer who shot Jermaine Baker will not face charges|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jun/14/met-officer-who-shot-jermaine-baker-wont-face-charges|accessdate=29 September 2017|work=The Guardian|date=14 June 2017}}</ref> |- | Richard Davies<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cambridgeshire-34601154|title=Man shot dead by police in St Neots, Cambridgeshire|accessdate=24 October 2015|date=22 October 2015}}</ref> | 21 October 2015 | St Neots, Cambridgeshire |Davies was fatally shot 15 minutes after police arrived, responding to a report of a domestic incident in a house.<ref name=":3" /> |- | James Fox<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-34105801 Man dies after being shot by police in north London], [[BBC News]], 31 August 2015</ref> | 30 August 2015 | London |Fox was shot by [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] armed officers after reportedly making threats to kill. |- | Dean Joseph<ref>[http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2014/09/05/london_police_shooting_first_since_2011.html First Fatal Police Shooting Since 2011 Reported in London], Slate.com</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-29074100 Islington man shot dead by Met Police officers], [[BBC News]], 5 September 2014.</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-29226978 Man shot dead by police in Islington named], [[BBC News]], 16 September 2014</ref> | 5 September 2014 | London |After holding a woman at gunpoint in an armed standoff with police officers, a police marksman fired two shots which resulted in the death of Joseph. The IPCC ruled that the killing had been in line with policy and was also lawful.<ref>https://www.ipcc.gov.uk/sites/default/files/Documents/investigation_commissioner_reports/Summary_Dean_Joseph.pdf</ref> |- | [[Anthony Grainger]] | 3 March 2012 | Cheshire |Grainger was shot and killed by an armed [[Greater Manchester Police]] officer in [[Culcheth]], Cheshire, on 3 March 2012. At the time, Grainger was unarmed. In January 2014 the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] announced that they would be prosecuting [[Chief Constable]] [[Peter Fahy]] under health and safety legislation over the shooting, and a full public inquiry into Grainger's death was announced in early 2016. |- | [[Death of Mark Duggan|Mark Duggan]] | 4 August 2011 | London |The [[Metropolitan Police]] stated that officers were attempting to arrest Duggan on suspicion of planning an attack, and that he was in possession of a handgun. Duggan died from a gunshot wound to the chest. The circumstances of Duggan's killing resulted in public protests in Tottenham, which led to conflict with police and escalated into [[2011 England riots|riots across London and other English cities]]. In January 2014 a jury returned the verdict of [[Justifiable homicide|lawful killing]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Mark Duggan inquest: Family fury at lawful killing decision|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-25657949|accessdate=27 August 2017|agency=BBC|publisher=BBC News|date=8 January 2014}}</ref> |- | Kingsley Burrell<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/may/15/kingsley-burrell-restrained-by-police-died-from-neglect-inquest-finds|title=Student restrained by police died from neglect, inquest finds|last=Halliday|first=Josh|date=2015-05-15|website=the Guardian|access-date=2016-07-28}}</ref> | 31 March 2011 | Birmingham | |- | Olaseni Lewis | 3 September 2010 | London |After being admitted to a mental health ward by his parents. Lewis died 3 days after a period of prolonged restraint by police officers. It was identified that a litany of failures by both police and medical staff that contributed to Lewis’s death.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/may/09/olaseni-lewis-died-in-part-from-disproportionate-use-of-force|title=Mother of man who died after police restraint calls for prosecution|last=Gayle|first=Damien|date=2017-05-09|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-06-12|last2=Dodd|first2=Vikram|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> However the misconduct case was dismissed on 6 October 2017 as claims of wrongdoing were "unproven" and any failings were "performance matters".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-41522864|title=Officers' restraint death case dismissed|date=2017-10-06|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-10-07|language=en-GB}}</ref> |- | Keith Richards<ref name="mail">[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1315288/Police-shot-dead-33-people-1995--marksmen-named.html Police have shot dead 33 people since 1995 - only two marksmen have ever been named]. [[Mail Online]].</ref> | 12 May 2009 | Shildon, Durham | |- | [[Death of Ian Tomlinson|Ian Tomlinson]] | 1 April 2009 | London |Tomlinson collapsed and died after being struck by a police officer during the [[2009 G-20 London summit protests|2009 G-20 summit protests]]. After an [[Inquests in England and Wales|inquest]] jury returned a verdict of [[unlawful killing]], the officer, Simon Harwood, was prosecuted for [[Manslaughter in English law|manslaughter]]. He was found not guilty but was dismissed from the police service for gross misconduct. |- | Mervyn Tussler<ref name="mail" /> | 8 May 2009 | Fernhurst, West Sussex | |- | David Sycamore<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/6067562/Man-shot-by-police-outside-Guildford-Cathedral-lawfully-killed.html ''Man shot by police outside Guildford Cathedral lawfully killed''], [[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] (Newspaper)</ref> | 30 November 2008 | Guildford, Surrey | |- | Andrew Hammond<ref name="mail" /> | 29 October 2008 | Harold Hill, London | |- | [[Death of Sean Rigg|Sean Rigg]] | 21 August 2008 | Brixton, London |Rigg died following a [[cardiac arrest]] while in police custody at the entrance to Brixton police station.The [[Independent Police Complaints Commission]] concluded that there was no evidence of neglect or wrongdoing and that the police had acted "reasonably and proportionately". The case became a [[cause célèbre]] for civil rights and justice campaigners in the United Kingdom, who called for "improvement and change on a national level" regarding deaths in police custody and the police treatment of suspects with mental health issues.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ipcc.gov.uk/sites/default/files/Documents/investigation_commissioner_reports/Rigg%20foreword.PDF|title=IPCC Report|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308054930/http://www.ipcc.gov.uk/sites/default/files/Documents/investigation_commissioner_reports/Rigg%20foreword.PDF|archive-date=2016-03-08|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref> |- | Habib Ullah<ref>{{cite news|title=Habib Ullah death: Seven-year wait for conduct hearing|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-beds-bucks-herts-32987783|accessdate=6 August 2016|publisher=BBC|date=4 June 2015}}</ref> | 3 July 2008 | [[High Wycombe]] | |- | Mark Saunders<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/the-killing-of-mark-saunders-929877.html ''The killing of Mark Saunders ''], [[The Independent]] (Newspaper)</ref> | 6 May 2008 | London | |- | Dayniel Tucker<ref name="mail" /> | 29 December 2007 | Stansted, Kent | |- | Ann Sanderson<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/8616579.stm|title=Jury shown police shooting CCTV|date=12 April 2010|publisher=|via=bbc.co.uk}}</ref> | 11 June 2007 | Sevenoaks, Kent |Sanderson was shot in an armed standoff with police in the early hours of June 11. Sanderson had a troubled past and diary extracts written by her detailed how she took comfort from self-harming and could trust no-one. She had bought an air rifle days before her death but a close friend said she did not think she had intended to commit suicide. The case was ruled as a [[lawful killing]] as Sanderson had instigated the incident.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/8652109.stm|title=BBC News - Woman shot dead by police lawfully killed, jury rules|website=news.bbc.co.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-06-05}}</ref> |- | Terry Nicholas<ref name="mail" /> | 15 May 2007 | Ealing, London |Nicholas was shot after brandishing a handgun at police officers attempting to arrest him, firing at least one shot in the process.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8255598.stm BBC News: 'Cunning plan' by police led to death]</ref> |- | Robert Haines<ref name="mail" /> | 31 October 2006 | New Romney, Kent | |- | Steven Colwell | 16 April 2006 | Ballynahinch, Co Down, Northern Ireland | |- | Philip Marsden<ref name="mail" /> | 19 December 2005 | Meir, Staffordshire | |- | Craig King<ref name="mail" /> | 10 September 2005 | Ashton-under-Lyne, Greater Manchester | |- | [[Death of Jean Charles de Menezes|Jean Charles de Menezes]] | 22 July 2005 | London |Menezes was a Brazilian man killed by officers of the [[Mayor's Office for Policing and Crime|London]] [[Metropolitan Police Service]] at [[Stockwell tube station|Stockwell Station]] on the [[London Underground]] after he was wrongly deemed to be one of the [[fugitive]]s involved in the previous day's [[July 21, 2005 London bombings|failed bombing attempts]]. These events took place two weeks after the [[7 July 2005 London bombings|London bombings of 7 July 2005]], in which 52 people were killed. The [[Independent Police Complaints Commission]] (IPCC) launched two investigations. In July 2006, the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] said that there was insufficient evidence to prosecute any named individual police officers in a personal capacity, although a criminal prosecution of the Commissioner in his official capacity on behalf of his police force was brought under the [[Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974]], on the failure of the [[duty of care]] due to Menezes. The Commissioner was found guilty and his office was fined.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ipcc.gov.uk/stockwell_one.pdf|title=STOCKWELL ONE|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20100908152737/http://www.ipcc.gov.uk/stockwell_one.pdf|archive-date=8 September 2010|dead-url=yes|access-date=|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7764882.stm|title=BBC NEWS {{!}} UK {{!}} Open verdict at Menezes inquest|website=news.bbc.co.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-06-05}}</ref> |- | John Mark Scott<ref name="mail" /> | 16 July 2005 | Stockfield, Northumberland | |- | [[Azelle Rodney]] | 30 April 2005 | London |Rodney was driven by associates Wesley Lovell and Frank Graham in a hired silver [[Volkswagen Golf]]. The three drove across north London after they were observed by police to pick up three weapons, believed to be [[MAC-10]] sub-machine guns. [[Specialist Firearms Command|Metropolitan Police Service]] [[specialist firearms officer]]s performed a Hard Stop manoeuvre in which one officer fired eight shots, 6 of which hit Rodney in the head, neck and chest. After a public inquiry led by [[Willy Bach, Baron Bach|Lord Bach]], it was found that the killing of Rodney was unlawful and eventually resulted in the case for prosecution of the officer who fired the fatal shots for the charges of murder. However, the jury found the officer not guilty.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/crime/azelle-rodney-killing-former-police-marksman-anthony-long-not-guilty-of-historic-murder-10364427.html|title=Azelle Rodney killing: Former police marksman Anthony Long not guilty|date=2015-07-03|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2017-06-11|language=en-GB}}</ref> |- | Simon Murden<ref name="mail" /> | 22 March 2005 | Hull, Humberside |Murden was alleged to have been suffering a psychotic episode. He left his house and drove a van against the flow of traffic which resulted in the collision with another vehicle. Murden abandoned the vehicle and took with what some witnesses described as a weapon. Armed police officers engaged and Murden sustained multiple gunshot wounds and was pronounced dead at the scene. An independent inquest ruled it was a lawful killing.<ref>https://www.ipcc.gov.uk/sites/default/files/Documents/investigation_commissioner_reports/simon_murden_exec_summary_v2.pdf</ref> |- | Nicholas Palmer<ref name="mail" /> | 12 May 2004 | Thornton Heath, London |Palmer was killed while on bail for arms offences, his death ruled as being lawful. |- | Philip Prout<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cps.gov.uk/news/latest_news/142_05/|title=CPS Statement on death of Philip Prout|date=2005-08-23|publisher=The Crown Prosecution Service}}</ref> | 4 May 2004 | Cornwall |Prout was shot during a siege in a village in Cornwall. He was allegedly carrying a samurai sword when he was killed. |- | Keith Larkins<ref name="mail" /> | 6 June 2003 | Heathrow Airport, London |Larkins, who was reported to be mentally ill, shot blanks from a replica firearm. Two police officers then fired on Larkins, resulting in his death. The incident was ruled as a lawful killing.<ref name="mail" /> |- | Derek Bennett<ref name="mail" /> | 16 July 2001 | Brixton, London |With a replica gun, Bennet threatened members of the public and then pointed the replica at armed police officers who fired on Bennet four times. Bennet had respotedly boasted to friends that the replica was real but on closer inspection it was revealed to be a novelty [[lighter|cigarette lighter]]. A verdict confirmed the case as a lawful killing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.richmondandtwickenhamtimes.co.uk/news/554559.Derek_Bennett__Lawfully_Killed_/|title=Derek Bennett 'Lawfully Killed'|website=Richmond and Twickenham Times|language=en|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref> |- | Andrew Kernan<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/july/13/newsid_2502000/2502889.stm|title=2001: Family demand inquiry into police shooting|date=13 July 2001|publisher=|via=bbc.co.uk}}</ref> | 21 July 2001 | Liverpool |Kernan suffered from [[schizophrenia]] and during an episode police were called to his home. He fled and brandished a samurai sword; after a stand-off two shots were fired and Kernan was killed. After a four-year inquiry the killing was deemed lawful.<ref name="bbc.co.uk" /> |- | Patrick O'Donell<ref name="mail" /> | 30 October 2000 | Islington, London |O'Donell was killed by police marksman after taking his mother and girlfriend hostage in a siege. |- | Kirk Davies<ref name="mail" /> | 24 September 2000 | Wakefield, West Yorkshire |Davies walked into a police station with an [[air gun]] and threatened the staff inside. A manhunt was launched and a tip-off to police eventually led to him being surrounded by armed officers outside Newton Lodge secure psychiatric unit, but Davies ignored repeated requests to give himself up before marksmen opened fire. Davies was taken to Pinderfields Hospital where he was pronounced dead. Davies was regarded as being "emotionally disturbed" and was suffering from PTSD after fighting in the [[Croatian Army]] in the [[Croatian War of Independence]]. It is believed he was suffering from [[posttraumatic stress disorder]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1356833/Police-shoot-dead-violent-ex-mercenary.html|title=Police shoot dead 'violent' ex-mercenary|last=Stokes|first=By Paul|work=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-06-05|language=en}}</ref> |}

==Multiple deaths in a single incident== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Names ! Date ! Location ! Description |- |style="white-space: nowrap;"| * Jane Boyle * James Burke * Daniel Carroll * Michael Feery * Michael ‘Mick’ Hogan * Tom Hogan * James Matthews * Patrick O’Dowd * Jerome O’Leary * William Robinson * Tom Ryan * John William Scott * James Teehan * Joe Traynor * [[Dick McKee]]* * [[Peadar Clancy]]* * [[Conor Clune]]* |21 November 1920 |Dublin, UK |[[Bloody Sunday (1920)]]
'''Bloody Sunday''' ([[Irish language|Irish]]: ''Domhnach na Fola'') was a day of violence in [[Dublin]] on 21 November 1920, during the [[Irish War of Independence]]. In total, 32 people were killed, including thirteen British soldiers and police, sixteen Irish civilians, and three [[Irish republican]] prisoners. This includes people who were mortally wounded, but died later. Royal Marines officer [[Hugh Montgomery (Royal Marines officer)|Hugh Montgommery]] was shot in the morning and died on 10 December, and three people who were wounded at Croke Park died later - Robinson and Carroll on 23 November and Tom Hogan on 26 November.
The day began with an [[Irish Republican Army (1917–22)|Irish Republican Army]] (IRA) operation, organised by [[Michael Collins (Irish leader)|Michael Collins]], to assassinate the '[[Cairo Gang]]' – a team of undercover British intelligence agents working and living in Dublin. IRA members went to a number of addresses and shot dead fourteen people (in addition, Montgomery was mortally wounded and died on 10 December): nine [[British Army]] officers (including Montgomery), a [[Royal Irish Constabulary]] (RIC) officer, two members of the [[Auxiliary Division]], two civilians, and one man (Leonard Wilde) whose exact status is uncertain.
Later that afternoon, members of the [[Auxiliary Division]] and RIC opened fire on the crowd at a [[Gaelic football]] match in [[Croke Park]], killing eleven civilians and wounding at least sixty, three of which died later (Robinson and Carroll on 23 November and Tom Hogan on 26 November). That evening, three IRA suspects being held in [[Dublin Castle]] were beaten and killed by their captors, who claimed they were trying to escape.
Overall, while its events cost relatively few lives, Bloody Sunday was considered a great victory for the IRA, as Collins's operation severely damaged British intelligence, while the later reprisals did no real damage to the guerrillas but increased support for the IRA at home and abroad. |- | * John Gallagher * Patrick Rooney * Hugh McCabe * Samuel McLarnon * Michael Lynch |14–15 August 1969 |Belfast and Armagh, Northern Ireland |[[1969 Northern Ireland riots]] |- | * Michael Flynn * Nicholas Payne |15 July 1987 |[[Plumstead]], London |Michael Flynn and Nicholas Payne were shot dead by police during an attempted armed robbery of a wages van at an abattoir in Shooters Hill. The marksman feared for the life of the van driver and fired on both of the assailants, who both died at the scene. |- | * Mark Nunes * Andrew Markland |13 September 2007 |[[Chandler's Ford]], Hampshire |Armed robbers. '''Mark Sweeten Wade''' (November 23, 1858 – 1929)[https://web.archive.org/web/20110605001249/http://www.getcited.org/mbrx/PT/2/MBR/10178919 GetCited.com ref] was a medical doctor and noted historian of early [[British Columbia]] history. A doctor at the [[Kamloops Home for Men]] in the 1920s, he was able to interview many veterans of the province's early gold rush, including many of the more famous names in the history of the [[Cariboo Road]], the [[Cariboo Gold Rush]] and the [[Overlanders of 1862 led by Thomas McMicking]].''The Cariboo Road'', Mark Sweeten Wade, preface''This is Cariboo'', ''[[Robin Skelton]]'', Introduction He also wrote on medical legislation and hospital policy in the province of British Columbia as well as a biography of explorer [[Alexander Mackenzie (explorer)|Alexander Mackenzie]]. His works have served as an important source of biographical and historical detail by later historians. ==Biography== :''This section is paraphrased from [http://kamloops.ca/museum/archives/pdfs/N56%20-%20Dr%20Mark%20Sweeten%20Wade.pdf ''"Dr. Mark Sweeten Wade"'', an unpublished typescript by Mary Gulliford] on the [[Kamloops Museum and Archives]] website. He was born in [[Sunderland, Tyne and Wear|Sunderland]], [[County Durham]], [[England]] on November 23, 1858. His parents were John Wade of [[Stockton-on-Tees]] and his mother was Mary Sweeten of [[Barnard Castle]]. After an education in British public schools (what would in North America be called private schools) and matriculated in the Faculty of Medicine at [[Durham University]]. He emigrated to Canada in 1881 and pursued further studies in medicine at [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] and returning to Canada in 1882 was hired as a medical officer for the [[Canadian Pacific Railway survey]] with the party surveying the Qu'Appelle, Regina, Moose Jaw and Swift Current area. In the fall of that year he returned to school at the [[University of Toronto]] General Hospital, finishing in 1883. He returned to England for a short visit, then upon re-entry to Canada at [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria, B.C.]] registered as a medical practitioner and took land in the [[Surrey, British Columbia|Surrey]] area near his brother Edmund Wade, practicing there until 1884. He hired on with [[Andrew Onderdonk]]'s construction operations for the [[Canadian Pacific Railway]], then based in [[Spences Bridge]] and [[Savona, British Columbia|Savona]]. There he met Emma Uren, daughter of [[James Bottrell Uren]], who ran the local hotel and also the ferry, on March 10, 1885. Upon the completion of the CPR he moved to [[Clinton, British Columbia|Clinton]] and was the resident physician there until 1889. In 1889 Wade went to [[San Francisco]] to study medicine at the [[University of California, San Francisco]], returning to live in Victoria after graduation and practicing medicine there until 1895. During a major [[List of smallpox epidemics|smallpox epidemic]] in 1892 he was appointed Chief Medical Officer of the province by [[Premier of British Columbia|Premier]] [[Theodore Davie]]. In 1895, he moved to [[Kamloops]] and open practice as an [[ear, nose and throat specialist]] in offices across from that city's ''Dominion Hotel''. A growing interest in newspaper writing led to his appointment as Editor of the ''[[Inland Sentinel]]'' when that paper's editor and publisher, [[Francis John Deane|F.J. Deane]], was elected as a [[Member of the Legislative Assembly]] of [[Legislative Assembly of British Columbia|British Columbia]] for [[Yale-West]] (which Kamloops was in at the time) and needed to be freed up from his editorial activities to pursue politics in Victoria and around the [[Electoral district (Canada)|riding]]. Although the provincial legislature as yet did not have political parties, both men were ardent [[Liberal Party of British Columbia|Liberal]]s and the newspaper espoused Liberal politics. In the same year he was appointed doctor for the Provincial Home for men and the local jail, and in 1899 he was appointed coroner and in 1900 elected vice-president of the Kamloops Liberal Association and also elected to the [[Board of Trade]]. Deane lost re-election in 1902 to [[F.J. Fulton]] and due to most such appointments in the province being from [[patronage]], Wade also lost his position as jail doctor and coroner. Deane bought the ''[[Nelson Miner]]'' in 1902 and renamed it the ''[[Nelson Daily News]]'', with Wade also contributing to it as a writer. In 1904 Deane sold the ''Inland Sentinel'' to Wade, who continued publishing it as a small paper covering only local and district news. In 1910, he tied the paper into a [[wire service]] and expanded it to eight pages as a weekly, covering world news and little local news. Wade's activities on the Board of Trade and a group known as the 10,000 Club (which like others of its time sought to promote growth in the city to a population of 10,000), Wade engaged in an advertising campaign to draw industries to the city, promoting ventures such as a tourist hotel, steamboat service on the [[North Thompson River]], a cannery, a creamery, a flour mill and a cold storage plant.. As part of his promotional zeal and in time for the Christmas sales market of 1907, Wade published ''The Thompson Country'', which biographer Mary Gulliford notes was error-ridden and "had an air of carelessness. It was probably due to increased demand for advertising of the Kamloops district that caused the hurried job." Wade also took part in the city's negotiations with the [[Canadian National Railway]] concerning sites for stations and [[workshop|shops]] in the Kamloops area for that railway's expansion of a line to the [[Okanagan]]. Wade helped organized the memorial service for King [[Edward VII]], held in the city's Riverside Park and was on the city's welcoming committee when [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Wilfrid Laurier|Sir Wilfrid Laurier]] came to town. He sold the ''Sentinel'' in 1912 and was elected alderman in 1913, retiring from the position and touring Europe briefly in 1914, returning to serve as a member of the medical board examining new recruits for the [[Canadian Expeditionary Force]]. During his lifetime Wade wrote two books other than ''The Thompson Country''. ''Mackenzie of Canada: The Life and Adventurers of Alexander Mackenzie, Discoverer'' was the first biography ever published on the famous explorer. His ''The Overlanders of '62'', which had been commissioned by the provincial government, was unfinished at the time of his death and was edited and published by provincial Archivist and Librarian [[John Hosie]] in 1932. His biographer summarizes
''"It was said of Wade as a historian "no pains in research were too strenuous" and certainly ''The Overlanders'' displays this trait. He possessed every scrap of evidence on the Overlanders that was to be had in diaries and correspondence and by word of mouth. The book is very meticulous and a fascinating work."
Wade died in 1929 leaving his wife Emma and son M. Leighton; another son, Daryl Fred, had died in 1920 after operating as an auto mechanic in Kamloops from 1912 and serving in the war from 1916 onwards to its completion. M. Leighton earned a [Bachelor of Science|B.Sc.] from [[McGill University]] and was involved in construction of the Mt. Olie power plant near Kamloops in 1913 and later supervised construction of hydroelectric development at Adams Lake, also becoming superintendent of the [[East Kootenay Power Co.]] in 1930 and from 1934 onwards was in charge of the Kamloops area highway department. ==Bibliography== *'' Notes on medical legislation in British Columbia'' (s.n., 1981) *''The Cariboo Road'' (Haunted Bookshop, Victoria BC 1979) *''The Overlanders of '62'' (publ. C. F. Banfield, printer to the King, 1931) *''The founding of Kamloops'' (publ. Inland Sentinel Press, 1912) *''Mackenzie of Canada'' (W. Blackwood & sons, Ltd., Edinburgh, 1927) *''[http://openlibrary.org/details/thompsoncountryb00wadeuoft The Thompson Country]'' by Mark Sweeten Wade (Inland Sentinel Print., 1907) (click link to read on-line) ==See also== *[[List of Canadian historians]] ==References== *[http://openlibrary.org/a/OL2311428A Open Library.org bibliography] {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wade, Mark}} [[Category:Canadian historians]] [[Category:Canadian male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Physicians from British Columbia]] [[Category:People from Kamloops]] [[Category:Cariboo people]] [[Category:University of California, San Francisco alumni]] [[Category:University of Toronto alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of Durham University]] [[Category:Canadian prospectors]] [[Category:Canadian coroners]] [[Category:1858 births]] [[Category:1929 deaths]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''Michael Simon Toon''' (born 12 March 1977) is an English photographer, filmmaker, designer and builder.
==Short films== Toon has made two short films in the style of [[cinéma vérité]] which are globally recognised as serious inquiries into the nature of life:
Toon self-produced ''[[Thought Moments]]'' (2004) which examines [[microexpressions]] by slowing down footage of a wide range of individuals answering seemingly innocuous questions. Toon, a former [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] monk,<ref>{{cite web |first=Caroline |last=McGhie |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/9611852/The-rise-of-the-Modernist-eco-friendly-home.html |title=The rise of Modernist, eco-friendly home |publisher= The Telegraph |date=26 October 2002 |accessdate=8 August 2013}}</ref> titled ''Thought Moments'' after the Buddhist term for the mental states we experience when a physical or mental object enters the mind. The film is part of the British Film Council's library.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://film.britishcouncil.org/thought-moments |title=Thought Moments |publisher=British Films Directory |date=12 January 2009 |accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref> It is also reproduced as coursework in [[neurolinguistic programming]] by students of psychology in several languages across the world.<ref>{{Cite web |first=Prof. |last=Ragodí |url=http://elbigotedebernays.blogspot.com/2009/11/trabajo-psicologia-1er-trimestre.html |title=Trabajo Psicología de 1er Trimestre El Bigote de Bernays |publisher=Blogspot |date=19 November 2009 |accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Hakan |first=Mirac |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kPVo6QyEaYk |title=Eye Accessing Cues |publisher=YouTube |date=18 March 2010 |accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9YEWK98aTog |title=Thought Moments |publisher=YouTube |date=13 May 2011 |accessdate=13 September 2017}}</ref>
Toon co-produced ''[[Protocell Circus]]'' (2010). He edited, treated, subtitled and scored footage of [[Abiogenesis#Complex biological molecules and protocells|protocells]] synthesised and filmed by Dr. Rachel Armstrong, Senior [[TED conference|TED]] Fellow and then [[University College of London]] teaching fellow.<ref>"Protocell Video by Michael Simon Toon." ''proto-futures: all things related protocell technology.'' Updated 27 Oct 2012.http://weheartprotocells.tumblr.com/post/34408108701/protovideo</ref><ref>"Rachel Armstrong: Applied scientist, innovator." Speakers, Ted.com. (c) TED Conferencing LLC. Accessed 7-31-13. http://www.ted.com/speakers/rachel_armstrong.html</ref> The film appears in numerous discussions on the origin of life in terms of synthetic biology.<ref>Schmidt, Marcus. "Production of synthetic biology in science, media, film and art." Life Workshop. Presentations of the meeting of the German Ethics Council 2011. Berlin. (C) 2013 German Ethics Council. Page 36.https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=de&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mpg.de%2F7423611%2Fwerkstatt_leben_tagungsdokumentation.pdf</ref> It was exhibited in 2010 at ''Digital Art@Google NYC'' at the Chelsea Art Museum of Manhattan and at ''Synth-ethic: Art and Synthetic Biology Exhibition'' in 2011 at the Natural History Museum of Vienna, Austria.<ref>"Digital Art@Google: We Write This To You From The Distant Future." 20 August – 22 October 2010. TheProjectRoom.org. http://theprojectroom.org/digitalartatgoogle2</ref><ref>"Living Chemistry & A "Natural History" of Protocells." © Synth-ethic: Art and Synthetic Biology Exhibition 2013. 14.05 – 26 June 2011 in the Natural History Museum, Vienna, Austria. Produced by Biofaction KG. Added 20 April 2011 21:09. http://www.biofaction.com/synth-ethic/?p=61</ref>
==Career== Toon demonstrates a [[Modern architecture|modernist]], [[form follows function]] methodology of design and build with an 'ultra-modern' aesthetic and emphasis on [[environmental design]].<ref>"Concept home sold off-plan for £2m." Birmingham Post. ''BirminghamPost.co.uk.'' Updated 25 Apr 2008 14:57. http://www.birminghampost.co.uk/lifestyle/house-homes/concept-home-sold-off-plan-2m-3961949</ref><ref>"Cannon Pendant Lamp Shade." Inspirations. Fab.com. Updated 2012. http://fab.com/inspiration/cannon-pendant-lamp-shade</ref><ref>McGhie, Caroline. "The rise of Modernist, eco-friendly home." ''The Telegraph.'' Posted 26 Oct 2012. Accessed 8-8-13. https://www.telegraph.co.uk/property/9611852/The-rise-of-the-Modernist-eco-friendly-home.html</ref>
===Angels' House=== Toon designed Angels' House, a 4,337 square foot energy efficient concept home in [[Weeford]] village, [[Lichfield]] of [[Staffordshire]], England, which in 2008 sold for £2 million, a record high sales price for a [[single family home]] in Staffordshire, more than 12 times the average home price in the county.<ref>"House Prices in Staffordshire." RightMove.com. Retrieved 30 July 2013.http://www.rightmove.co.uk/house-prices-in-Staffordshire.html</ref> Toon formed Case Study Construction, referencing the [[Case Study House Program]] of [[Santa Monica, California]], which from 1945 to 1966 commissioned and published plans for ideal homes by major designers of the day including [[Charles Eames]] and [[Mies van der Rohe]]. Angels' House sold while in construction based on computer generated images of the finished project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghampost.co.uk/lifestyle/house-homes/concept-home-sold-off-plan-2m-3961949|title=Concept home sold off-plan for £2m|first=Birmingham|last=Post|date=25 April 2008|publisher=}}</ref>
===Furniture=== Toon has released four interior furnishing and architectural installation designs under the Si-Huis brand of the Los Angeles-based company California Design and Build, LLC.<ref>California Design and Build. Facebook Page. https://www.facebook.com/californiadesignandbuild/wall</ref>

Updated 2012. http://fab.com/inspiration/bi-plane-floor-lamp</ref> *Cannon Pendant Lamp Shade (2012)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fab.com/inspiration/cannon-pendant-lamp-shade|title=So into this design on Fab! Cannon Pendant Lamp Shade #FabForAll|website=Fab.com}}</ref> *Crane Light (2013)<ref>" Si-Huis Crane Lights, illuminated by other Si-Huis Crane Lights. Carbon fiber composite, polyester and rubber. Designed for the [[Philips Hue]] bulb. Design and build by MST." California Design and Build. Facebook Page. Posted 17 Jan 2013 8:04. https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=600259969989975&set=a.600222599993712.154333.120894934593150&type=1</ref>
